Award.AwardTitle: Self-assembled organic nanotubes from cyclic ureas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program at the National Science Foundation supports the work of Professor Linda Shimizu of the University of South Carolina that investigates the utility of functional porous crystals to absorb, transport and organize guests and to facilitate their subsequent photoreactions. These porous crystals are made by the self-assembly of bis-urea macrocycles into columnar structures. The columns pack close together to give crystals with homogeneous channels with diameters of 1 nm or less. The mobility of the guest through cylinder like nanochannels is a function of the dimensions (size, shape) and interior properties (polarity) of the channel. The Shimizu group studies photoreactions and oxidations in these small spaces. These reactions provide controlled model systems to test the effects of confinement on reactions.

Fundamental understanding of the processes of absorption, diffusion, and storage in tiny straw-like channels with diameters of 1 nm or less has practical application in separations and catalysis. Ultimately, a better understanding of a reaction mechanism aids in the development of safer, more environmentally friendly and economical reagents for organic synthesis. This research provides training for undergraduates and graduate students in organic and materials chemistry. In addition, this award supports the continuation of a chemical demonstration program that brings chemists into South Carolina K-12 classrooms to showcase the scientific method and to foster interest in chemistry and in the natural sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program at the National Science Foundation supported the work of Professor Linda Shimizu of the University of South Carolina to investigate the utility of functional porous crystals to absorb, transport and organize guests and to facilitate their subsequent photoreactions. These porous crystals are made by the self-assembly of bis-urea macrocycles into columnar structures.   The columns pack close together to give crystals with homogeneous channels with diameters of 1 nm or less. The mobility of the guest through cylinder like nanochannels is a function of the dimensions (size, shape) and interior properties (polarity) of the channel. The high purity and tiny size of the straws enabled the study the diffusion of atomic xenon gas through the channels.  Under high pressure, xenon atoms diffuse one by one in single file through the smallest of the straws.  In comparison, in the larger 0.9 nm straws, xenon atoms show normal diffusion.  The diffusion was studied in collaboration with Professor C. Russ Bowers at the University of Florida.     

 

Fundamental understanding of the processes of absorption, diffusion, and storage in tiny straw-like channels with diameters of 1 nm or less has practical application in separations and catalysis. This award enabled the study of photoreactions, oxidations and the polymerization of isoprene within these columnar channels.  These reactions provide controlled model systems to test the effects of carrying out reactions in confinement and resulted in ten peer-reviewed publications.  Computational methods were developed to better understand the photoreactions observed within the straws.  The long-term goal is to be able to accurately predict the reactivity of a wide range of small organic molecules within nanostraws.  Ultimately, a better understanding of a reaction mechanism aids in the development of safer, more environmentally friendly and economical reagents for organic synthesis. This research provided partial support and training for seven graduate students, twelve undergraduates, and six high school students in organic and materials chemistry. In addition, this award supported our chemical demonstration program that brings chemists into South Carolina K-12 classrooms to showcase the scientific method, to foster interest in chemistry and in the natural sciences, and to highlight career opportunities in the STEM fields.  Over the award, the program made 38 visits to K-12 schools in South Carolina, presenting 117 shows to ~3500 students.
